Real-time manufacturing modeling and simulation framework using augmented reality and stochastic network analysis
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 14 May 2018

Real-time manufacturing modeling and simulation framework using augmented reality and stochastic network analysis

  • Hyunsoo Lee1 

Virtual Reality volume 23, pages85–99(2019)Cite this article

  • 668 Accesses

  • 5 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

While the development of augmented reality (AR) technologies has made it possible to assign real-time features to many systems and applications, these trends are rare in manufacturing modeling and simulation. This research study proposes a real-time manufacturing layout modeler and material flow simulator. The manufacturing devices of interest are positioned using AR labels, and the generated layout is converted into a stochastic Petri net model, where the validity of material flow and other criteria are checked. In order to overcome the limitations of the Petri net model and enhance analytical functionalities, stochastic network analyses are embedded into the framework. The layout model with greater uncertainty is analyzed, and manufacturing performance indicators such as cycle time, throughput, and work-in process are estimated. The proposed framework is not simply an integration of AR techniques and manufacturing simulations, but provides an efficient AR labeling architecture for large-scale manufacturing environments, and is suitable for a fast, real-time rendering. In order to verify the effectiveness of the proposed framework, real-time modeling and simulation examples were used as case studies. The results showed that the proposed system contributes to more accurate layout design and simulation analysis by using the embedded AR techniques and queuing network methods.

Introduction

Virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) technologies have been applied extensively in various fields such as gaming, information-based guiding systems, manufacturing systems, commerce, and other service platforms. This research study focuses on their manufacturing design and simulation. Manufacturing was among the first areas where VR technologies were applied. These research trends (Banerjee and Zetu 2001) were called “Virtual manufacturing.” The initial VR applications were the software employed to design manufacturing devices by using computer-aided design (CAD) models. Several components of manufacturing equipment were parameterized, and a new device was modeled by controlling them in a virtual environment. The subsequent emergence of immersive devices accelerated the development of computer-aided virtual environments (CAVEs) for manufacturing. For instance, virtual assembly can be experienced indirectly using VR glasses and haptic gloves in a VR space. The primary applications of VR in manufacturing relate to modeling, operations, experiments, and testing. Even though VR technologies are applied extensively to manufacturing, their use for real-time monitoring and simulations is limited. Because real-time manufacturing information is gaining considerable importance, many attempts have been made to use AR technologies. The primary uses of AR technologies are to offer additional manufacturing information to related engineers and workers. For instance, an AR label might provide an exit in emergency situations in a factory or guide a job sequence. While VR technologies are considered comparatively weak in reflecting real-time information, AR-based applications are limited in extensive modeling and simulations in general.

In order to overcome these limitations, this research integrates both techniques and analyses—AR techniques and manufacturing simulations. In particular, a layout generation and its analyses are considered an application. While there are many commercial simulation modeling and analysis tools, they lack real-time functions, such as material flow design considering the manufacturing environment in real time. As spatiotemporal information is crucial for accurate manufacturing simulation, this paper integrates these data and supports manufacturing simulations and analyses through AR labeling. When a new materials’ flow is required, or the existing layout needs to be modified, the relevant engineers and experts have a discussion meeting where the given manufacturing environment is captured in real time. A material flow is then designed using Petri net-based modeling approaches. The candidate positions for a new device or existing facilities are labeled with AR marks. The validity of the generated layout and flow is checked by embedding Petri net analysis modules. In order to overcome the limitations of Petri net-based approaches and obtain more accurate manufacturing performance indicators such as cycle time, throughput, and work-in process (WIP), stochastic network-based methods of analysis are used in the proposed system. As information processing and rendering speeds are primary issues in AR-based systems, an effective structure and methods to manage the mapping relations between AR labels and real-time objects are provided. The proposed framework is a real-time manufacturing layout modeling and analysis system that uses AR labeling, Petri net modeling, and queuing network analysis.

The following section provides the related background and a literature review, including comparisons of the proposed method with similar applications. Section 3 explains the overall framework of the AR-embedded virtual manufacturing simulator. In order to handle more uncertainties in manufacturing transitions and estimate performance indicators, stochastic network approaches are provided in Sect. 4. The effectiveness of the proposed framework is verified with case studies in Sect. 5.

Background and literature review

This paper proposes a new framework that incorporates manufacturing layouts as well as their simulation and analyses using AR technologies in real time. This section elaborates the related background and reviews the relevant literature and applications.

Manufacturing layout, simulation, and AR/VR-based applications

As spatiotemporal and uncertain information is embedded into manufacturing environments, most manufacturing layout problems (Qi 2010; Lee et al. 2001) are NP-hard or NP-complete. Moreover, dynamic situations, such as the breakdown of a manufacturing device or insertions of new material flows (Kim et al. 2013; Abadi et al. 2010), render the manufacturing environment more complex. As a result, a designed layout or a materials’ flow might become invalid or ineffective.

In order to validate a modeled layout and prove its effectiveness, simulations and layouts are essential procedures. Due to its NP-hard complexity, a designed layout can fail to satisfy optimal objectives, and designs need to be modified repeatedly. In such a situation, the reference of manufacturing information presenting the given visible manufacturing scene is crucial.

While many research studies and applications have addressed the handling of manufacturing layouts and their simulations, real-time layout modeling and simulations have traditionally been studied comparatively scarcely. This might have been due to immature real-time information acquisition technologies and a lack of integration frameworks for this purpose. However, these limitations have been overcome in recent years with the development of the relevant technologies. Many contemporary studies, including Zhang et al. (2015) and Qu et al. (2016), have provided integrating frameworks of manufacturing devices using the Internet of Things (IoT) technologies. As mentioned in the previous section, these trends have accelerated with the introduction of VR and AR technologies. Many conventional manufacturing simulators support VR-based layout design and analyses. Table 1 summarizes the functions and characteristics of commercial manufacturing layout software.

As shown in Table 1, contemporary layout and simulation software support a 3D modeling-based layout design. While smart manufacturing or smart factory is one of the leading paradigms in manufacturing systems, those softwares are considered as implementation tools for cyber-physical system (CPS) which is a core module in the smart factory. According to relevant research studies (Lee et al. 2015; Lachenmaier et al. 2017; Kusiak 2017; Lee 2017a, b), a CPS is an integrated system consisting of physical systems, cyber systems, and their interactions. In general, physical systems indicate a target manufacturing processes or modules in real world. While it is difficult to apply several improving efforts on the manufacturing spot in real time without their verifications, cyber systems are considered test beds for the simulations and verifications. In order to reduce the gaps between both systems and update the latest situations, data, information, and related controls are shared in both systems using manufacturing Internet of Things (IoT) and cloud environments. The software shown in Table 1 is considered several implementation tools for the cyber system currently. However, these softwares are limited with several reasons. The main limitations are the weak interaction with physical systems in real time. As mentioned in the previous section, these 3D models were developed in the early stages of VR modeling and are simulated only using predefined logics. While a realistic and detailed 3D layout view is created using these softwares, simulations and analyses functionalities are weaker than in general simulation software (Table 2). In particular, crucial criteria for layout design—such manufacturing performance indicators as WIP, cycle time, and throughput—are not analyzed as much.

While commercial discrete-event simulators support better simulation and analysis features, they are limited in terms of the detail of the layout design using a 3D VR model. Furthermore, both types of layout modelers and simulators fail to incorporate real-time design functions.

Several research studies have proposed real-time design frameworks for manufacturing modeling and analysis using AR-based techniques. Table 3 summarizes these studies.

As shown in Table 3, existing AR-based manufacturing systems support real-time processing for layout design, parts’ manipulation, training, and experiments. However, most of them only weakly support their process simulations. Moreover, the analysis functions are deficient, because of which an AR-based system is used only as an auxiliary module for decision making in manufacturing. It indicates that it is difficult to implement a CPS module with the contemporary relevant software in real time. In order to overcome this limitation, this research proposes an AR-based manufacturing modeler with analysis functionalities. The provided architecture and framework is considered a more effective implementation tool for a CPS in smart manufacturing systems.

Petri net model and stochastic network analysis

The proposed system incorporates a Petri net-based modeler and queuing network-based approaches to analysis. While several real-time modeling methodologies have been proposed, their usability and evaluation issues are remaining. In order to resolve the issues, both evaluation methods (Petri net-based analyses and stochastic network analyses) are integrated. The usage of Petri net-based modeling and evaluation prevents frequent modeling mistakes (e.g., ambiguity between states and transitions, wrong connection among states/transitions, or deadlock-occurring simulation model). In addition, the accurate simulation status is verified using its simulations with several analyzing features (e.g., reachability, liveness, and boundedness). While Petri net-based approach helps the easy modeling, monitoring, and analyses using its simulation, it is required to analyze the more scenarios with various uncertainties. These requirements are fulfilled with the usages of stochastic network analyses. These mechanisms contribute to the improvement of the usability and accurate evaluations.

Petri net can help model material flows and check the validity of the designed layout. An ordinary Petri net is defined with a five tuple (\(\{ P,T,I,O,m\}\)). \(P\) indicates a set of places representing devices or stations in manufacturing applications, \(T\) is a set of transitions from a partial set of \(P\) to another partial set of \(P\), and \(m\) is the set of the initial number of tokens in \(P\). Each token can be interpreted as a material, a WIP, or a manufacturing resource. \(I\) and \(O\) are considered mapping functions expressed by (1) and (2):

$$I:P\,X\,T \to N$$
(1)

where N = the set of natural numbers

$$O:T\,X\,P \to N$$
(2)

These mapping functions are used to guide materials from one manufacturing device to another or set other manufacturing constraints. A complex manufacturing layout can be represented using these notations and functions of the Petri net. Many manufacturing layouts and operations’ problems (Zhou et al. 2015; Zhou and DiCeasre 2012; Recalde et al. 2004; Lee et al. 2008) have been modeled using Petri net and solved using its analysis features, such as reachability, liveness, and boundedness. These features are used to check the validity of a modeled layout and identify unused manufacturing devices, unused transitions, and the maximum capacities of states in the layout. The detailed analyses and their implementations are provided in Sect. 3.3.

While Petri net is used widely in manufacturing design, monitoring, and analysis, several Petri net variations have been proposed. Colored Petri net introduces colored tokens to describe different types of manufacturing resources or materials. Another use of colored Petri net is to simplify an ordinary Petri net. As one disadvantage of the Petri net is its complex structure, the introduction of colored tokens makes a Petri model simpler. The other popular variation is the stochastic Petri net (Haas 2002), which contains a stochastic time delay in each transition. For instance, a time delay between two places can be represented using a Gaussian distribution with a mean of 15 units of time and a variance of 3.5. The Petri net model with stochastic time delay is useful for representing manufacturing flows with variation-type uncertainties.

The proposed framework represents a layout using an ordinary Petri net. Then, when additional stochastic time delays reflecting manufacturing uncertainties are mapped to the model, the net is converted to a stochastic Petri net. The stochastic Petri net is then used as a basic materials’ flow model in this research.

Another limitation of Petri net modeling is its weak analysis feature for estimating such manufacturing performance indicators as WIP, throughput, cycle time, and states with longer bottlenecks. These indicators are important criteria for determining the effectiveness of a material flow. As general analyses are performed using token simulations in Petri net models, it is difficult to analyze these indicators by considering various uncertainties in manufacturing. In order to overcome this limitation, this research incorporates analyses using the queuing network model. Queuing network approaches (Curry and Feldman 2011; Buzacott and Shanthikumar 1963) have been used widely to model and analyze manufacturing systems with uncertainties. Lee (2017a, b) used them to analyze multi-site and multi-process manufacturing environments using the Internet of Things (IoT)-based cloud architectures. This paper uses stochastic network-based analysis as a basic mechanism to estimate important manufacturing performance indicators. The estimated statistics are used to quantitatively measure the effectiveness of the manufacturing layout in real time. The embedding stochastic network analysis and the related implementation are provided in Sects. 4 and 5, respectively.

Framework of augmented reality-based virtual Petri net simulator

Modeling and simulation procedures of virtual Petri net simulator

As discussed in the previous section, AR-embedded analysis features yield several benefits for existing simulation tools. While many conventional manufacturing modeling and simulation tools are available, efforts to reflect the manufacturing site and environment have been ignored in the literature by comparison. In the past, a representative simulation methodology was discrete time-based event handling. The overall manufacturing process is analyzed and modeled into several states. With discrete time, materials and assembly components are moved from one state to another state with fixed routings. Stochastic time delay (Lee and Banerjee 2009), predefined schedules, or other manufacturing constraints are considered with these transitions. While these simulation tools evaluate the performance (e.g., cycle time, throughput, WIP, and states with longer bottlenecks) of the manufacturing models, most of them fail to incorporate another aspect—the spatiotemporal information of the manufacturing environment. For instance, spatiotemporal information is crucial for making manufacturing decisions in cases of a factory-layout embedding simulation, materials’ routing design, and the reconfiguration of factory architecture. Several research studies (Yang et al. 2013; Ding et al. 2010) have attempted to incorporate spatiotemporal manufacturing information into models using VR techniques. While these frameworks are effective for delivering the positions and movements of the elements involved in manufacturing, there are several limitations, such as construction burdens, on the VR components, and a lack of interaction between VR models and the simulation model.

In order to overcome these limitations, this paper proposes a new and effective manufacturing simulation framework that incorporates spatiotemporal information using AR techniques. The framework reflects changes in the real-time manufacturing environment. For instance, the breakdown of a machining tool can influence changes in the material handling routes. If an alternative machine is in the factory at a different workstation, the existing routes and related information (e.g., transition periods and states) need to be reflected in the simulation model in real time. From these perspectives, augmented reality technologies are considered the most suitable tool for incorporating real-time manufacturing environments into a simulation model.

This study uses a Petri net model as basic simulation modeling framework. Its characteristics and advantages have been discussed in the previous section. While other Petri net modelers and simulation tools (Lee et al. 2007) establish a network model without considering real-time manufacturing scene information, as shown in Fig. 1a, the proposed framework (Fig. 1b) constructs a manufacturing layout model reflecting dynamic changes in real time.

As the proposed framework supports augmented reality features, the input of the system consists of real-time image frames acquired from an installed camera module. The target manufacturing sites would be captured using a device with a camera module. The sites would consist of inner spaces in a factory or a workstation cell. Process engineers, experts, and related officials would then discuss the possible layout and routes using the real-time images. The possible positions and layouts of manufacturing facilities are represented using “state” in the embedded Petri net modeler. This state is interpreted as a place in the Petri net model. The moving routes of materials are described using the “transition” symbol. The generated Petri net model is depicted on the real-time images. As shown in Fig. 2, the operator can determine the exact layout of the manufacturing facility using the real-time image frames.

During these modeling processes, the designers can assign an AR label to each state. The embedded AR labels enable the potential layout of the manufacturing facility and its related simulations to be understood clearly. The detailed labeling methods are provided in the following section. The Petri net model is subsequently finalized with the required information for the simulation stage. Table 4 describes the required information for simulation and analysis.

After finalizing the Petri net model, its simulation was run with analyses using Petri net methodologies. Section 3.3 provides the detailed techniques and features. The simulations and analyses provide key performance indices, such as WIP, throughput, and cycle time. Moreover, states with longer bottleneck or resource efficiencies can be analyzed using the embedded queuing network analysis. Figure 3 shows the overall procedure of the framework.

Augmented reality labeling structure and image acquisition

Unlike other modeling tools, the proposed framework provides AR labels symbolizing manufacturing equipment, such as various machining tools, robots, and conveyor belts. These labels help clearly understand “states” in a Petri net. As mentioned in Sect. 2, a weakness of many Petri net models is the complex structure and related semantics. While a general Petri net uses only three kinds of symbols (circle, rectangle, and arrow), this simplicity is an advantage as well as a disadvantage. For instance, it is difficult to capture the meaning of a state without a detailed legend. These disadvantages are addressed using AR labels as shown in Fig. 4.

Each AR label indicates the means of handling, transporting, or processing materials in a manufacturing factory. Many research studies, including Joshi and Smith (2012), have classified manufacturing equipment and devices in terms of handling materials. The usual partitioning consists of material handlers (MH), material transporters (MT), material processors (MP), and storage devices (SD). A conveyor belt or an automatic guided vehicle belongs to MT. They are used to transport materials. MP indicates the devices processing the materials. A lathe, a milling machine, an injection machine, or other chemical processing machines usually belong to MP. In order to pick up materials and move them to a predefined position, MHs, such as a robot or a human, are used. SDs are used for intermediate storage during a process. As the developed framework targets a simulation model covering a real-time manufacturing environment, it uses these classifications. Figure 5a shows the implemented AR marks. CAD models, photographs, and sketches depicting manufacturing devices are used for these marks.

Three types of devices per MH, MP, and MT are modeled and represented as AR labels. Additional AR marks can be modeled and inserted into the framework. For instance, AR marks for the automotive industry are different from those for the chemical industry (Fig. 5b). While a 3D AR mark is effective for depicting an immersive manufacturing environment, it is limited in adding AR labels and synthesizing AR-embedded image frames in real time. For this reason, this research uses a 2D AR label. The use of 2D AR marks guarantees fast rendering and a short computation time.

While most of AR applications use AR labels only to show addition information, the AR labels help plan the layout of the related devices and the generations of more suitable material routing in the system. For this reason, it is important to consider the size and orientation of an AR mark. For instance, the direction of installation and the size of the conveyor belt influence the overall layout of the manufacturing equipment and devices. Even though a robot is positioned in the same place, its different orientations create different flows of materials. In addition, too big or too tiny an AR mark might result in misinterpretation of the generated layout. In order to prevent the occurrence of such situations, Euler angler-based resizing and reorientation transformation (3) is applied to a new conversion to \({\text{AR}}_{\text{s}}^{\text{new}}\).

$${\text{AR}}_{\text{s}}^{\text{new}} = T_{\text{scale - Rotation}} (k_{x} ,k_{y} ,\theta_{z} ) \cdot {\text{AR}}_{\text{s}}$$
(3)

where \({\text{AR}}_{\text{s}}\) = the original image of an AR label, and

$$T_{\text{scale - Rotation}} (k_{x} ,k_{y} ,\theta_{z} ) = \left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}l} {k_{x} \cdot { \cos }\;\theta_{z} } \hfill & { - { \sin }\;\theta_{z} } \hfill & 0 \hfill \\ {{ \sin }\;\theta_{z} } \hfill & {k_{y} \cdot { \cos }\;\theta_{z} } \hfill & 0 \hfill \\ 0 \hfill & 0 \hfill & 1 \hfill \\ \end{array} } \right]$$

When simulation analysts and layout designers determine a location for an AR mark, the scale parameters (\(k_{x} ,\,k_{y}\)) and a rotation parameter (\(\theta_{z}\)) are estimated through comparisons with the real-time manufacturing environments captured by participating engineers. Each coordinate in an AR image is then converted into a homogeneous coordinate and then a new transformed AR label using (3). As the AR label is a 2D image, only rotation along the Z-axis is considered. Finally, an AR label of suitable size and orientation is embedded on the real-time image frames.

Another issue in AR labeling is the complicated mapping from labels to states and their related semantics. As contemporary manufacturing environments are becoming larger and more complicated, redundant and duplicated process modeling might occur. This situation gives rise to the need for a large memory and incurs a more complicated computational burden. Lee and Banerjee (2011) proposed an effective framework for large-scale manufacturing environments—the Metaearth architecture. This study applies Metaearth to the main mechanism to map AR labels to a Petri net model and real-time image frames. As the proposed simulator requires real-time image processing techniques, the incorporation of the effective mapping structure helps downsize the processing memory and lessen the related computation burden. As shown in Fig. 6a, the original version of Metaearth consists of four layers: a virtual space layer, a mapping layer, a library layer, and an ontology layer. This architecture is applied to the AR-based framework as shown in Fig. 6b.

As shown in Fig. 6b, the ontologies (MH, MP, and MT) are connected to the AR library layer, which is a memory with predefined AR marks. The layer (AR-embedded flow layer) with a generated Petri net has references to AR labels in its state nodes to minimize labeling redundancies and additional memory usage. The suitable location, size, and rotated angle are estimated using (3) and saved in the mapping layer. While there are seven manufacturing devices, four AR labels are referenced only using the Metaearth architecture. As an effective AR labeling mechanism, the modified Metaearth architecture contributes to reducing redundant memory and increasing the information processing speed for faster rendering.

Real-time image acquisition is implemented using a camera module embedded on a computer system or a stand-alone vision system. While the developed system can use both types of vision systems, this research study uses a commercial image acquisition tool—Microsoft Kinect—for the tests and verification. Table 5 provides the detailed specification of the AR-based Petri net simulator.

As main tools of implementation, C++ and MATLAB were used. AR labeling and the related image syntheses were implemented on C++. The Petri net simulation and the related user interfaces were implemented on MATLAB. While the maximum image resolution in the proposed framework was 2560 × 1600, 1280 × 960 was set as resolution in light of Kinect’s ability. These RGB image frames were partitioned at 30 frames per second (FPS). Each FPS has AR labels using image-synthesizing mechanisms of the proposed framework in real time. As operators and analysts add AR marks and create a Petri net model, each divided real-time image is synthesized with artificial symbols and reconstructed into new image frames.

The following section elaborates upon the use of the proposed Petri net model.

Verification using Petri net features

As discussed in Sect. 2, the Petri net methodology is used as the main modeling and simulation framework in the proposed simulator. This feature allows the framework to share the analytical features of the Petri net model, such as reachability and liveness. Furthermore, the framework checks the validity of the designed layout and the material flows. Table 6 shows the incorporated features in the proposed framework.

The validity of the generated Petri net model is verified using adjacent nodes. The advantages from the usages of Petri net-based approaches are provided in Sect. 2. The frequent modeling mistakes are prevented using its embedding grammars, and the simulation accuracies are guaranteed with its finite automata features. According to the definition of a Petri net, a state’s adjacent node needs to be a transition or transitions. Similarly, a transition needs to be linked to a state or states.

While there is rarely a modeling mistake in software that handles only Petri nets, the implemented framework is used not only for modeling and simulation of Petri nets, but also for generating the layout of manufacturing facilities in real time. A node (state or transition) might be connected to the same type of node. Moreover, a node exists without any connection to other nodes. In manufacturing processes, the existence of independent nodes is considered incorrect design or a deficiency in optimal material flows. In order to prevent these modeling errors, the suggested framework checks the validity of the model using (4) and (5). When these rules are violated, a warning appears in the information panel of the developed tool. The system modelers and analysts then identify and correct these errors. In Petri nets, reachability indicates marking information (\(m_{j}\)) that another marking information item (\(m_{i}\)) can reach after firings of relevant transitions (\(t_{k}\)), as shown in (6). This feature can identify a place/state that has no token concerning the manufacturing operation in spite of being connected to other nodes. This feature is useful in removing “dead nodes” in a material flow. A similar concept in transition is liveness. A Petri net is considered live if there is a sequence of transition firings to enable a transition from a marking information item.

Boundedness is related to the maximum capacity of a manufacturing device. When the maximum number of tokens (B) is identified using (7) in a Petri net model, this information can be utilized as a manufacturing constraint or additional design consideration. These analyses benefit from the usage of Petri net-based modeling. Using these embedding methods of analysis, the validity of the designed material flow and the characteristics of manufacturing devices are identified. Figure 7 shows an example where the generated material flow has an invalid layout (a connection between two places without a transition) and the framework generates a warning to redesign.

Analysis using stochastic network

The proposed AR-based Petri net simulator is equipped with an analysis methodology, queuing network-based manufacturing performance analysis. While the Petri net methodology is useful to check the reachability and monitoring of a system, another technique is required for the embedded features, stochastic time delay, or uncertain manufacturing rules. Even though the stochastic Petri net (Bause 2002) and other variations are available, frameworks that analyze manufacturing performance using Petri net and general probability distributions are rare. In order to handle more uncertain manufacturing environments, the framework incorporates the stochastic network approaches of Curry and Feldman (2011) and Buzacott and Shanthikumar (1963).

While other manufacturing analyses use Markovian properties to analyze multi-processes manufacturing system, this research handles more general manufacturing situations—Markovian processes and non-Markovian processes. Each transition has a mean duration and a related variance during a transfer from a state to another. While each state indicates a manufacturing device or a resource, and has an AR label, each transition has a stochastic time delay. The proposed framework converts a Petri net into a queuing network using these transitions. As shown in Fig. 8a, a stochastic Petri net is considered with variation-type uncertainties in each transition.

A general stochastic network has as inputs the inter-arrival velocity (\(\lambda_{1}\)) and the inter-service velocity (\(\mu_{i}\)) of each server (\(j\)). These velocities contain additional probabilistic information, such as the density function, the coefficient of variance (CoV), and other characteristics (e.g., the Markovian or non-Markovian property). In a Petri net, the transition time delay (\(\lambda_{1}\)) of the initial tokens is mapped to the inter-arrival velocity in the converted queue model. The time delays in the intermediate transitions (\(\mu_{i}\)) are then considered as inter-service velocities of the relevant servers. When layout designers enter this information in a Petri net, it is converted to a compatible stochastic network. This research considers general-type distributions (Dror et al. 2002) covering both properties, Markovian processes and non-Markovian processes, for more extensible applications.

The cycle time (\({\text{CT}}_{i}\)) is estimated using (8) (Curry and Feldman 2011; Buzacott and Shanthikumar 1963) in a general process (\(i\)):

$${\text{CT}}_{i} = \left( {\frac{U}{1 - U}} \right) \cdot \frac{1}{{\mu_{i} }} \cdot \left( {\frac{{C_{a}^{2} (i) + C_{\text{s}}^{2} (i)}}{2}} \right) \cdot \left( {\frac{{U^{{\sqrt {2C + 2} - 2}} }}{c}} \right) + \frac{1}{{\mu_{i} }}$$
(8)

where \(U = {\raise0.7ex\hbox{${\lambda_{1} }$} \!\mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{\lambda_{1} } {\mu_{i} }}}\right.\kern-0pt} \!\lower0.7ex\hbox{${\mu_{i} }$}}\), \(C\) = the number of resources of the process \(i\), \(C_{a}^{2} (i) = {\raise0.7ex\hbox{${V[\lambda_{1} ]}$} \!\mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{V[\lambda_{1} ]} {E[\lambda_{1} ]^{2} }}}\right.\kern-0pt} \!\lower0.7ex\hbox{${E[\lambda_{1} ]^{2} }$}}\) and \(C_{s}^{2} (i) = {\raise0.7ex\hbox{${V[\mu_{i} ]}$} \!\mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{V[\mu_{i} ]} {E[\mu_{i} ]^{2} }}}\right.\kern-0pt} \!\lower0.7ex\hbox{${E[\mu_{i} ]^{2} }$}}\)

In the converted queuing network, each connection is classified into three types of links: a serial, a merging, or a branching connection. In case of a partial Petri module with a serial connection as shown in Fig. 8b, its cycle time (\({\text{CT}}_{\text{Serial}}\)) is calculated with the sum (\(\sum\nolimits_{i = 1}^{2} {{\text{CT}}_{i} }\)) of each cycle time using (8). However, the arrival of the second process (j) CoV (\(C_{a}^{2} (j)\)) has to be recalculated as it is influenced by the \(\lambda_{1}\) and \(\mu_{i}\) of the previous state. Then, the arrival CoV is estimated using (9) and plugged into (8). Finally, the overall cycle time is calculated with the sum of each cycle time:

$$C_{a}^{2} (j) = \left( {1 - \left( {\frac{{\lambda_{1} }}{{\mu_{i}^{{}} }}} \right)^{2} } \right) \cdot C_{a}^{2} (i) + \frac{{\lambda_{1} }}{{\mu_{i}^{{}} }} \cdot \left( {\frac{{C_{\text{s}}^{2} (i) + \sqrt {c_{1} } - 1}}{{\sqrt {c_{1} } }}} \right)$$
(9)

where \(c_{1}\) = the number of resources at process \(i\)

Merging connection is used frequently for modeling assembly processes, for collaborative works, or for increasing the utilization of resources in many manufacturing environments. In the connection, the essential feature is the calculation of an approximate mean time and its variance covering overall input arrivals, as shown in Fig. 8c. The integrated arrival velocity is calculated using (10):

$$\mu_{\text{total}} = \sum\limits_{i = 1}^{n} {\mu_{i} }$$
(10)

Then, the subsequent arrival CoV (\(C_{a}^{2} (j)\)) is estimated using (11). Each \(C_{d}^{2} (i)\) is obtained using (9). Finally, it is considered as one process; then, (8) is applied to calculate cycle time:

$$C_{a}^{2} (j) = \sum\limits_{i = 1}^{n} {\frac{{\mu_{i} }}{{\mu_{\text{total}} }} \cdot C_{d}^{2} (i)}$$
(11)

In case of a branching connection as shown in Fig. 8d, it is divided into two types of branches. The first pattern indicates separation using a predefined manufacturing rule or fixed constraints. For instance, a module might be transmitted to one of several identical machining tools for subsequent manufacturing tasks. A criterion for selecting one of these might be the idleness of the machines. In this situation, cycle time is calculated using (8) under these criteria. The other pattern is the case of branching with predefined probabilities. These probabilities can be used to control the work balance among machine tools. The cycle time in this pattern is calculated with the newly estimated CoV (\(C_{a}^{2} (j)\)) using (12):

$$C_{a}^{2} (j) = p_{i} \cdot C_{d}^{2} (i) + (1 - p)$$
(12)

When the overall cycle time (\({\text{CT}}\)) is estimated using the provided formulae, the other manufacturing performance indicators such as WIP (\(L\)) and throughput (\({\text{TH}}\)) are calculated using Little’s law (13).

$$L = {\text{CT}} \cdot {\text{TH}}$$
(13)

Furthermore, the efficiency (\(\rho_{i}\)) of a state (\(i\)) is calculated using (14), and manufacturing equipment with longer bottlenecks can be identified:

$$\rho_{i} = {{\lambda_{i} } \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{\lambda_{i} } {(c \cdot \mu_{i} )}}} \right. \kern-0pt} {(c \cdot \mu_{i} )}}$$
(14)

where \(\lambda_{i}\) = inflow velocity to state \(i\), c = the number of resource at process \(i\), and \(\mu_{i}\) = service velocity to state \(i\)

The incorporation of queuing network-based analysis helps estimate the manufacturing performance indicators of the generated material flow more accurately. Many research studies including Lee (2017a, b) applied the queuing network-based approaches for evaluating the manufacturing systems, and its usability has been proved. The existence of AR labels and the use of stochastic network analysis are the core features in determining a manufacturing layout by considering simulations and analysis in real time. The following section provides exemplary case studies using the proposed/manufacturing simulations and analysis.

Manufacturing simulation and case studies

Manufacturing plants producing airplanes were considered as case studies. When a new layout to overcome the limitations of an existing manufacturing environment is required, the new positions of the manufacturing devices and changes to the materials’ flow are simulated and analyzed using the proposed framework in real time.

While the real-time images can be obtained using any camera module on the system, Microsoft’s Kinect was used in these case studies.

The scenario began with a meeting with the process engineers, layout designers, and simulation experts to reconstruct existing material flows and install new manufacturing equipment. While discussions took place with the prepared potential layouts and analyses, it was possible to simulate new and effective layouts and design them on the spot in real time. The manufacturing engineers and experts determined the possible positions of the manufacturing devices to be installed by checking the real-time image frames (Fig. 9a). The manufacturing plant had several floors to produce an airplane. This indicated that several manufacturing devices were installed on different floors, and a simulation incorporating these layouts needed to be considered. The related Petri net model (Fig. 9b) and AR labeling (Fig. 9c) were generated using procedures provided in Sect. 3.

A state was considered a position for a newly installed manufacturing device, and an AR label was mapped in the generated Petri net. Operators entered a period at a transition between two adjacent states. After checking the validity of the Petri net, manufacturing performance indicators were calculated using queuing network-based analyses (Fig. 10).

The simulation is shown in the figure along with the movements of the tokens. Each token indicates a material in the manufacturing plant. The estimated simulation results and the related information are provided in Table 7.

Furthermore, the efficiency of each state (of each manufacturing resource) and states with longer bottlenecks is identified using the simulations and analyses. Engineers and modelers can discuss the designed layout and its flow and modify or innovate the route. Figure 11 shows another real-time modeling and simulation procedure for a layout in a production plant for a device.

The application supports real-time layout generation and its analyses. While the validation of the layout is checked using the analytical features of the embedded Petri net, many useful simulation results can be estimated by simultaneously using the stochastic network model.

Conclusion and further studies

This paper proposed a framework that integrates a real-time layout design and its simulations. While similar tools create layouts using custom modeling, long modeling times and isolation from the given manufacturing environment are considered to be the main limitations. In order to overcome these, an AR-based layout and real-time simulator were integrated in the proposed framework.

The given manufacturing environment is recorded using a camera module in a system. A new and efficient material flow is then designed using Petri net modeling methodologies. The position of a production device is determined using its state and its duration represented using a transition in the model. The use of Petri net modeling methods incurs many advantages in analyzing the created layout, such as the validity of the model, reachability, and liveness. Manufacturing performance indices such as WIP, throughput, and cycle time are analyzed using the embedded queuing network approach. As these simulations and analyses are executed using real-time image frames acquired from manufacturing plants, more accurate decisions and discussions are possible. The framework contributes to efficient material flow design in a vacant factory or redesigns of existing workplaces.

In future work, more realistic AR marks will be considered with richer contents. While the current framework uses 2D AR marks for considering rendering speeds, 3D volume-based marks can yield more realistic images to attending engineers. To this end, more effective database structures and real-time rendering techniques need to be implemented. One interesting possible variation is the integration of sketch-based recognition into the proposed framework. While a manufacturing device is inserted or modified with the graphic user interface in the system, engineers and modelers can discuss possible layouts and draw using a digital pen on the screen featuring real-time image frames. The sketch is identified, and the Petri net model will be generated automatically. These scenarios can make the design and analyses of layouts and flows more immersive and productive.

The proposed framework is considered an integrated system combining real-time manufacturing modeling and its analyses. The proposed framework can be a core module for many applications handling real-time manufacturing layouts and their analyses.
